column2: Role: Battery System Architect (Lithium-Ion - EV) Location: Pune Battery system architecture in the context of electric vehicles (EVs) encompasses the design, integration, and management of various components that make up the battery system. Here's an overview of the key aspects of battery system architecture: As a Lithium Battery Design Architect, this role involves conceptualizing, designing, and overseeing the development of lithium-ion battery systems for various applications such as electric vehicles, energy storage systems, consumer electronics, and industrial equipment. Here are the key responsibilities and skills associated with this role: Key Responsibilities: 1.   System Architecture Design: Define the overall architecture and configuration of lithium-ion battery systems based on project requirements, performance targets, and safety standards. Determine the cell chemistry, cell arrangement (series/parallel), module configuration, and pack design for optimal energy density, power output, and efficiency. Work on several architectural topology for cell and pack configurations Ex. Cell to Module to Pack, Cell to Pack, Cell to Chassis etc. 2.   Cell Selection and Evaluation: Evaluate and select appropriate lithium-ion cell types (e.g., LFP, NCA, LMFP, Solid State, and any new chemistry) based on energy density, cycle life, cost, safety characteristics, and application-specific requirements.  Collaborate with cell manufacturers or suppliers to assess cell performance, conduct testing, and validate cell specifications for integration into battery systems. 3.   Battery Management System (BMS): Design the Battery Management System (BMS) architecture, including hardware components (sensors, controllers) and software algorithms for cell balancing, state estimation, thermal management, and fault detection. Develop BMS features for monitoring cell voltage, current, temperature, state of charge (SOC), state of health (SOH), and implementing safety protocols (e.g., overcharge protection, thermal runaway prevention). 4.   Packaging and Integration: Develop packaging solutions and mechanical designs for housing lithium-ion cells/modules within battery packs, considering factors such as space constraints, cooling requirements, weight distribution, and structural integrity. Integrate battery packs with electronic components (inverters, chargers), cooling systems (liquid or air-cooled), and electrical interfaces (connectors, cables) for seamless integration into end-use applications. 5.   Charging System: The charging system is part of the battery architecture and includes components like charging ports, onboard chargers, and external charging infrastructure (charging stations). Charging protocols (e.g., CCS, CHAdeMO, Type 2) and communication interfaces (CAN bus, Ethernet) are integrated into the battery system architecture to support charging operations and data exchange. 6.   Integration with Vehicle Systems: The battery system architecture interfaces with other vehicle systems such as the powertrain (electric motors, inverters), vehicle control units (VCUs), and infotainment systems. Communication protocols (e.g., CAN bus, LIN bus) are used to exchange data between the battery system and other vehicle components for coordinated operation and control. 7.   Safety and Compliance: Ensure compliance with safety standards (e.g., UN ECE R100, IEC 62619, ISO 26262) and regulatory requirements related to lithium-ion battery design, transportation, storage, and usage. Incorporate safety features such as cell/module insulation, venting mechanisms, short-circuit protection, and emergency shutdown systems to mitigate risks of thermal runaway or electrical hazards. 8.   Performance Optimization: Architect and Optimize battery system performance through design iterations, modelling, simulation, and testing to achieve desired energy capacity, power output, charging efficiency, and cycle life. Architect and influence the selection of components for battery pack, BMS and peripheral components so as to overall impact on the best-inclass efficiency, reliable pack while the cost is kept under control as per business target. Conduct performance validation tests (e.g., charge-discharge cycles, capacity retention, aging tests) and analyse data to improve battery system reliability and longevity. 9.   Cost Analysis and Optimization: Conduct cost analysis, bill of materials (BOM) optimization, and supplier negotiations to achieve cost-effective solutions without compromising quality, performance, or safety. Identify opportunities for cost reduction, material substitution, and manufacturing efficiency improvements in lithium-ion battery design and production processes. 10.   Collaboration and Documentation: Collaborate with cross-functional teams (engineering, manufacturing, quality assurance) to ensure alignment with project timelines, budget constraints, and technical requirements. Create technical documentation, specifications, design guidelines, and standard operating procedures (SOPs) for lithium-ion battery design, development, and manufacturing processes. 11.   Scalability and Future-Proofing: Modern battery system architectures are designed for scalability and future-proofing to accommodate advancements in battery technology, increased energy density, and evolving vehicle requirements. Modular designs, standardized interfaces, and upgradable firmware/software enable manufacturers to adapt to changing market needs and technological advancements. Skills and Qualifications: Bachelors or masters degree in engineering/ electrical engineering, Mechanical Engineering/Battery Technology or related field. Proven experience (15+ years) in lithium-ion battery design, development, and integration, preferably in automotive, energy storage, or electronics industries. At least 10+ years experience in working with both LV&HV LiB system architecture design for EV 2/3/4 wheeler, E-Bus from 72V to 650V system. Expertise in battery system architecture, cell chemistry, BMS design, thermal management, and safety standards/regulations (e.g., ISO 26262, UL 1642). Adequate exposure in CAD software (e.g., SolidWorks, AutoCAD) for mechanical design, 3D modelling, and packaging layouts. Understand several battery testing equipment (e.g., cyclers, impedance analysers), data analysis tools (MATLAB, Python), and simulation software (COMSOL, GT-Suite, ANSYS). Knowledge of manufacturing processes for battery production (cell assembly, module assembly, pack assembly), quality control procedures, and supplier management. Strong problem-solving skills, analytical thinking, attention to detail, and ability to work in multidisciplinary teams. Excellent communication skills, project management capabilities, and a proactive approach to innovation and continuous improvement in lithium battery design.

This role requires a deep understanding of electrical engineering, mechanical engineering, and automotive systems tailored to the unique challenges and requirements of EV 2/3-Wheeler. Here are the key responsibilities and skills associated with this role:   1. Powertrain Architecture: The Powertrain Architect is responsible for conceptualizing and designing the entire powertrain system of a vehicle, including the selection of components, integration of subsystems, and overall architecture. Design and/or optimize the electric powertrain components for 2-Wheeler and 3-Wheeler vehicles, including the motor, battery system, power electronics, and transmission. 2. Traction Battery: Fair understanding and knowledge about battery suitability for two-wheeled EVs, considering factors such as energy density, weight, charging time, and range optimization. 3. Electric Motors & Controller: Expertise in electric motor design, performance characteristics, torque delivery, and efficiency, max. efficiency point, controlled parameters, customised fine point analytics tailored to the dynamics and requirements of two-wheelers. 4. Energy Management Systems (EMS) & Power Electronics: Understanding and implementing power electronics components like inverters, converters, and motor controllers optimized for lightweight and compact designs suitable for two-wheelers. Developing and integrating software algorithms for efficient energy use, regenerative braking, thermal management, and overall powertrain optimization for both low and high-speed two-wheeler EVs. 5. Electrical Systems and Architecture: Design the vehicle's electrical architecture, including wiring harnesses, electrical distribution systems, power electronics, sensors, actuators, and controllers (e.g., Vehicle Control Unit).Integrate electrical systems with the vehicle's mechanical and electronic components for seamless operation and control. 6. Vehicle Control Systems: Design and develop control algorithms, software, and firmware for vehicle control systems, including traction control, stability control, regenerative braking, and driver assistance features. Implement cybersecurity measures, communication protocols (CAN bus, LIN bus), and diagnostic capabilities for real-time monitoring and control. 7. Integration, Testing and Validation: Comprehensive understanding of how the electric powertrain influences the handling, acceleration, braking, and overall performance of electric motorcycles and scooters. Conducting rigorous testing (H-I-L & S-I-L), simulations in system software and validation procedures to assess the performance, reliability, and durability of the electric powertrain in diverse operating conditions relevant to two-wheelers. 8. Compliance and Regulations: Ensuring that the powertrain design meets safety standards, emissions regulations, and other legal requirements specific to two-wheeled electric vehicles in different regions. 9. System Performance Optimization: Conduct simulations, modelling, and testing (e.g., dynamometer testing, vehicle testing) to validate system performance, energy efficiency, range estimation, and thermal management. Optimize system parameters, control strategies, and calibration settings for optimal vehicle dynamics, acceleration, braking, and energy consumption. 10. Safety and Compliance: Ensure compliance with safety standards, regulations (e.g., ISO 26262), and homologation requirements for electric vehicles, including crashworthiness, electrical safety, and emissions compliance. Design safety-critical systems, redundancy strategies, and fail-safe mechanisms to mitigate risks and ensure vehicle safety. 11. Supplier Management and Collaboration: Collaborate with suppliers, OEM partners, and third-party vendors to source components, subsystems, and technologies for the EV system architecture. Manage supplier relationships, negotiate contracts, conduct technical evaluations, and ensure component quality and reliability. 12. Integration and Collaboration: Collaborating with cross-functional teams, including mechanical engineers, software developers, designers, and suppliers, to integrate the powertrain seamlessly into the two-wheeler platform while considering space constraints and weight distribution. Person should be a go getter keeping abreast of the latest advancements in EV technology, cutting edge technology, smart control mechanism, deep analytic mind to visualize, understand and foresee technology as an enabler for both top line competitiveness and bring innovation to the floor. Have a haunch for generating Ips and Patents in several areas but not limited to Power train domain.   Skills and Qualifications:  Bachelors or masters degree in mechanical/electrical/automotive engineering, or related field. Additional certifications or training in EV technologies are beneficial.  Proven experience (18+ years) in electric vehicle system design, architecture development, and integration, preferably in the automotive or EV industry.  Expertise in EV components and subsystems, including powertrains, battery systems, charging infrastructure, electrical systems, and vehicle control systems.  Have strong exposure in Power-train system of EV- 2/ wheeler with critical interplay between several components of EV system, optimization, redundancy and safety.  Understand, interpret, and guide in CAD software (e.g., SolidWorks, CATIA) for system modelling, simulation, and design visualization.  Knowledge of automotive engineering principles, safety standards/regulations (e.g., ISO 26262, UN ECE R100), and homologation processes for EV certification.  Experience with software development, control algorithms, embedded systems, and CAN communication protocols for vehicle control and diagnostics.  Strong analytical skills, problem-solving abilities, and attention to detail for system optimization, performance analysis, and troubleshooting.  Excellent communication skills, project management capabilities, and ability to work in cross-functional teams to deliver complex EV system projects on time and within budget.
